utterances: Well, you know, I can tell you all the stories you want.
The trouble is that they're very, very hard to test.
But let me give you one example since your previous interviewee was talking about climate change.
In fact, the very warmest temperatures of any time in the last 65 million years occurred within this range of 50 to 55 million.
We call this the thermal maximum for the Cenozoic for the last 65 million years.
And the way to think about this just in metaphorical terms, it's as if you took the climate of a place like Texas and moved it 20 degrees north to where Minnesota is.
Theâ€¦
Wow, that's some shift.
We've got about less than a minute left.
What do you need to do, I mean, is this going to take years and years to find that what happened at that crossover point?
Why one went up, one went down?
What we do is we take them back to our regional office.
We have a big chest freezer and we put them to sleep permanently in the freezer.
You just stick them in the freezer?
Yeah.
It takes - you know, we leave them in there for 24 to 48 hours to make sure that they're thoroughly frozen.
But that's sort of a kinder, gentler way to get rid of them.
What can people, particularly people listening in South Florida, what can they do to defend themselves?
Well, they just need to be on the lookout for these snails.
And we have a toll free helpline.
Like I said, it's kind of us against the snails.
And the residents that have had hundreds of these in their yard right on the block where they were likely established, they're quick to tell you anything you can do to get rid of them.
Richard Gaskalla is the director of plant industry at Florida's Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services.
He's working to get rid of the giant African snails, an invasive species that's arrived to South Florida.
Richard, thank you.
And good luck.
Thanks a lot.
This is MORNING EDITION from NPR News.
Good morning.
I'm Linda Wertheimer.
And I'm Renee Montagne.
A delegation of mayors came to Washington this week, lobbying for a slice of the economic stimulus package.
As we heard earlier, the plan is still being debated in the Senate, though a vote could come today.
The mayors are hoping to get federal dollars directed to local programs in their cites, which are hurting.
Antonio Villaraigosa of Los Angeles was one of the mayors who made the trip.
He's back in his home city, where we called him and asked how the recession was affecting Los Angeles.
Well, last week, President Obama said the worse-case scenario would be a double-digit unemployment rate.
We're there here in Los Angeles.
The unemployment rate is over 10 percent.
Last year, the foreclosure rate was four times higher than the year before.
People are hurting right now.
And that's why we were in Washington, D.C., to tell politicians, you know, we can't afford to dillydally with this and bicker.
The Republicans have criticized the stimulus package as not necessarily jump-starting the economy.
But give us some examples of projects that you're hoping to get funding for that would, in fact, lead pretty directly to jobs.

We have a solar initiative here in Los Angeles that over an 11-year period, beginning right away, will produce about 1,200 megawatts of solar power, the most ambitious solar initiative in the United States of America.
We have a clean-air action plan at the port, the largest port in the United States.
That clean-air action plan has, as a component, an effort to retrofit 16,000 dirty diesel trucks to clean-fuel vehicles.
We just passed Measure R in Los Angeles, the half-cent sales tax that will invest $40 billion in public transportation, highway repair.
These are the kinds of initiatives that we can get off the ground right away with a federal partnership.
As you've just suggested, people in Los Angeles County voted to tax themselves.
So are you, in sense, just asking the government to match what the people in that region are willing to do themselves?
That's right.
Los Angeles has not gone to Washington, D.C., with its hand out.
We've gone with our arm out to extend a partnership with the federal government to get people back to work.
The other thing we're saying is, invest directly in cities and municipalities.
When you think about it, some 84 percent of the population lives in metropolitan areas.

So when you give money directly to the states, take off the top and then give back to the cities, you're not getting the best bang for the buck, and you're not moving these projects as quickly as possible.
Traditionally, federal money has flowed through the state.
The State of California is in dire straits right now.
Why push for money to go directly to your city, Los Angeles, when it will come through the states to you?
Because when it goes that way, you never get your fair share.
That's why.
We're 26 percent of the population in California.
We oftentimes get 12 percent of the money, sometimes, 16, 18.
But that's after a fight.
Now, I'm not saying that money shouldn't go to the states, but not as much money as going under this plan.
Antonio Villaraigosa is the mayor of Los Angeles.
Thank you for joining us.
You're welcome.
To sign into law a major overhaul of the banking system.
The House has passed the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act, but the Senate has yet to vote.
Democratic senators are waiting for West Virginia's governor to replace the late Robert Byrd.
The bill has been called the greatest change to our financial system since the Great Depression, and yet there are many issues that remain unclear.
And here to talk about that is Adam Davidson of NPR's Planet Money team.
Hi, Adam.
Hey, Robert.
And there are a lot of details in this huge bill, but what's missing from it?
Well, it's a huge bill.
I've been trying to make my way through it and it is so dense and filled with so much detail that it's sort of shocking to learn how much isn't in the bill.
Congress has left an awful lot of the details up to regulators and a variety of commissions to figure out how best to regulate the financial system.
Congress created broad goals, then it's up to the other folks to fill in the fine details.
Give us a couple of examples of questions that are left for the regulators to answer.
Sure.
A perfect one is: What do we do when a huge financial firm the government determines is systemically important, what do we do when they are in danger of collapse?
Do we bail them out?
Do we allow them to collapse?
This is a question that is left unanswered.
You mean the resolution authority, to fold it down?
Well, thank you so much and mas oro, more gold.
Of course, the car companies can also sell those very same cars - there's nothing weird or exotic about them - everywhere in the United States.
So, you know, if they have a concern about enforcement or working with the various states, we've invited them to come in and talk with us.
We're eager to talk with them, but this is not going to be a tough thing for them to do.
Polls show that environmental issues are of concern to the American public, but they're farther down on the list, below the economy and health care and some other issues.
Will a program like this make cars more expensive?

Well, this is one of the areas where I think the auto companies have been shooting themselves in the foot because they continually argue that this new program is somehow going to add thousands of additional dollars to the price of a vehicle.
That's just not true.

We think that, on average, the additional cost of compliance, which get us to a 30 percent improvement in fuel economy by the year 2016, the cost of that is going to be less than $400 on the price of the vehicle.
And even with low gasoline prices which, frankly, we and every body else think is not going to last all that long, this is going to be paid back in a matter of a couple of years.
So, we're talking about a solid investment.
The president's decision to sign this order and to do so so early in his administration, what do you think that signals about this new administration and its approach to environmental policy?
Well, I think the first thing that it signals is that this is a president who intends to make good on the big commitments that he made in the course of his campaign.
He's done a number of things in his first week or two in office to signal that he means to reverse bad decisions from the previous administration and set us on a different course.
This one is from our perspective, of course, a no brainer, but really it is a very significant move.
And I think...
Can I just jump in here, though?
Is it a signal of the direction that he intends to follow, or could it possibly be interpreted as a poke in the eye to Republicans?
Oh, I don't think so.

I think that there were many Republicans, including former administrators of EPA, who agreed with California - not to mention my boss, Governor Schwarzenegger, who's also a Republican in good standing.

The Bush administration's position was opposed by their entire career staff, and I think it's a signal that he intends to honor the technical and scientific advice that he's hearing from all of his staff that this is something that needs to be done.

Even more significant, I think in some ways, is the fact that he's also ordered the Department of Transportation to take another look at their fuel economy standards and to take a more aggressive stance on those, as well.
So, this is not just a one shot deal or a political move in my opinion.
It's a sign of a real shift.
Mary Nichols, thanks so much for talking to us.
Thank you.
Mary Nichols is the Chair of the California Air Resources Board.
In the World War I novel All Quiet on the Western Front, it was said that every soldier believes in chance but trusts his luck.
NPR's Tom Bowman spoke with the Marine serving in Anbar Province in Iraq about the luck that saved his life.
